p:
In the experiments, we first determine the position of the sample plane by measuring the out-of-plane torque as a function of angle Θ from the z-axis (Supplementary Fig. 2). The measurements of τ(Θ) curves are repeated at various Φ. Figure 3a shows typical curves of τ(Θ) for p ≈0.11 at 80 K in the superconducting state. At this temperature, τ(Θ) exhibits a sharp change when H crosses the ab plane. The data are fitted by a symmetric polynomial function, and accordingly, we precisely determine the alignment of the ab plane, Θ
ab , at which τ(Θ) = 0. Supplementary Fig. 3b shows Θ
ab , as a function of angle Φ for p ≈ 0.11. Via computer control of the vector field and mechanical rotator systems, we eliminate the misalignment ΔΘ
m at each Φ. Then we rotate H within the ab plane with a field misalignment better than 0.1°, without changing setup or removing the sample. Measurements of τ( ϕ) curves are repeated at all the temperatures in Fig. 4. By analysing all the twofold oscillation curves, we obtain the temperature dependences of χ
ab and χ
aa − χ
bb . After completing all the experiments, the sample alignment is double checked at 80 K to confirm that the sample did not move during the measurement.
